I was thinking that 1:20 reduction would work, but are there any other ways to calculate this ratio. We want a fast elevator

Need way more information.

Cascade or continuous elevator?
What motors?
How many motors?
How heavy is the carriage?
Is there any counterbalancing?
How far does it need to travel?
How fast do you want it to travel?

https://ambcalc.com/startup?=

AMB calc supports deceleration, unlike recalc, and its results match up with custom simulations. Use a load force of the weight plus friction minus counterbalancing, and the mass being the moving mass, while the radius is the spool diameter. If you are using cascade, you will need to manually account for the upduction after running the calc.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-01-14T14:42:40.024Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":410,"readers_count":409,"score":107.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":481463,"topic_slug":"how-can-we-calculate-gearing-ratio-for-elevator","display_username":"Ada","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/feedback-on-elevator-design/481554/8","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"Feedback on Elevator Design","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":9246,"username":"BordomBeThyName","name":"Matt Golman","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bordombethyname/{size}/147649_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":69084,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-can-we-calculate-gearing-ratio-for-elevator/481463/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3482370,"name":"Matt Golman","username":"BordomBeThyName","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bordombethyname/{size}/147649_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-14T19:01:24.957Z","cooked":"

The one variable I forgot to ask about is the diameter of the drum/pulley/sprocket (for rope/belt/chain respectively) that you‚Äôre using to move the first stage.

@Alex_Y linked the AMB calculator, which is a great resource for this, so let‚Äôs use that.

image1798√ó1299 240 KB

  1. Here‚Äôs where you can input what motors you‚Äôre using. In this case, two NEOs (the calculator doesn‚Äôt distinguish between the NEO 1.0 and 1.1, they‚Äôre very similar).

  2. Here is how much power we want to draw when operating. 10A is a good ‚Äúguesstimate‚Äù of how much current a large mechanism should draw when moving. I also changed the 12V to 10V to buy myself some margin.

  3. This is the radius of the pulley/sprocket/drum that I mentioned above. I don‚Äôt know what you‚Äôre using, so I put in the pitch diameter of a 16T no. 25 chain sprocket. I found that information in the ‚ÄúCAD and Drawings‚Äù section of WCP‚Äôs website here.

  4. This is where you put in the weight of the stuff you have to move. ‚ÄúMass‚Äù is the total weight of the moving parts of the elevator. Cascade elevators have a funky little calculation you have to do here. You‚Äôre directly lifting the first stage, but for every inch the first stage moves, the carriage moves two. That means that the ‚Äúeffective‚Äù mass you‚Äôre lifting is the first stage plus twice the carriage. Edit: Because of physics beyond the scope of this post, gear ratios get squared here, so the ‚ÄúMass‚Äù here is actually 4 times the carriage mass. The screenshot above doesn‚Äôt account for this. I‚Äôm guessing at a 5lb first stage and a 10lb carriage here (5 + 4*10 = 45). You‚Äôll have to put in more accurate numbers.
    The ‚ÄúLoad Force‚Äù is going to be the lifting force minus however much force you‚Äôre offsetting with constant-force springs. I‚Äôm guessing 15lbs, but again you‚Äôll have to put in numbers that match what you‚Äôre actually building.

  5. The target distance is how much the first stage of the elevator moves, in this case 26" (half of the 52" that the carriage moves). I also set the 'stopping type" to ‚Äústopped‚Äù to simulate the motor stopping the elevator, rather than driving the elevator into its hard stops.

The graph at the bottom shows how long the elevator takes to move for different reductions. The 20:1 that you initially proposed takes about 1.7s to move to position (with the guesses I made about your elevator mass and sprocket diameter). To move in less than 1s, you need a reduction of about 12:1. In theory the fastest you can get this elevator is about 0.6s with a 5:1 reduction, but I would caution against choosing the absolute fastest ratio in case you‚Äôre off on your estimates of mass or efficiency. If this was mine, I would probably select something like 8:1.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-01-14T21:29:13.463Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":275,"readers_count":274,"score":65.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":481463,"topic_slug":"how-can-we-calculate-gearing-ratio-for-elevator","display_username":"Ada","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":9246,"username":"BordomBeThyName","name":"Matt Golman","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bordombethyname/{size}/147649_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":69084,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-can-we-calculate-gearing-ratio-for-elevator/481463/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3482570,"name":"","username":"Alex_Y","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-14T21:36:37.818Z","cooked":"
BordomBeThyName:

That means that the ‚Äúeffective‚Äù mass you‚Äôre lifting is the first stage plus twice the carriage. I‚Äôm guessing at a 5lb first stage and a 10lb carriage here (5 + 2*10 = 25).

Gear ratios get squared in inertia calculations (you can find this out if you work directly with the governing differential equations). You need to add four, or two squared times the carriage mass.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-01-14T21:36:45.867Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":8,"reads":274,"readers_count":273,"score":129.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":481463,"topic_slug":"how-can-we-calculate-gearing-ratio-for-elevator","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50219,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/how-can-we-calculate-gearing-ratio-for-elevator/481463/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3482598,"name":"Elijah Palm - 1792 Design Lead","username":"Abyss1792","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/abyss1792/{size}/234338_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-14T21:45:37.192Z","cooked":"

This is a very useful tool from 1678

1678 Parts Tracking and Design Tool Spreadsheets Technical
Hello teams! During our First in Focus webinar hosted by 2468 a while back, we promised to release the spreadsheets we use for parts tracking and design calculations. So, here are the parts tracking spreadsheet and the design tool spreadsheet. The links are to view-only templates, so go to File > Make a copy in order to get an editable copy for your team. Parts Tracking Tabs: Part List: a sort of ‚Äúfront page‚Äù where all of your numbered parts are displayed with information such as status, qua‚Ä¶

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-01-14T22:28:28.574Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":238,"readers_count":237,"score":52.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":481463,"topic_slug":"how-can-we-calculate-gearing-ratio-for-elevator","display_username":"Matt Golman","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":50219,"username":"Alex_Y","name":"","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":9246,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Retired üå¥"},"post_url":"/t/how-can-we-calculate-gearing-ratio-for-elevator/481463/11","custom_user_title":"Retired üå¥","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3482923,"name":"Drew Williams","username":"jreneew2","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jreneew2/{size}/135239_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-15T01:36:25.149Z","cooked":"

So if I am reading this correctly‚Ä¶

To generalize an N-stage elevator. The calculation for the mass the motor is lifting is

(mass of first moving stage) + (2^2 x mass of second stage) + ( 3^2 x mass of third stage) ‚Ä¶ (N^2 mass of N stage)?

Or am I completely misunderstanding?

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-01-15T01:51:13.194Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":12,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":213,"readers_count":212,"score":57.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":481463,"topic_slug":"how-can-we-calculate-gearing-ratio-for-elevator","display_username":"Matt Golman","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":21777,"username":"jreneew2","name":"Drew Williams","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jreneew2/{size}/135239_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":9246,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Retired üå¥"},"post_url":"/t/how-can-we-calculate-gearing-ratio-for-elevator/481463/13","custom_user_title":"Retired üå¥","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3483048,"name":"","username":"Alex_Y","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-15T03:49:43.196Z","cooked":"

Yes.

Suppose we have a generic system with a velocity input and some gear ratio \alpha with an interatance I. Let F_m be the force provided by the velocity input, and F_a be the force acting on the intertance.

We can say
F_{in} = \frac{F_a}{\alpha}
F_a = I \ddot{x_a}
\dot{x_{in}} = \alpha \dot{x_a}

Substituting, we get
F_{in} = \frac{I \ddot{x_a}}{\alpha}

However, this accerleation is in the wrong reference frame, x_a is in the output frame, while we are looking at the input frame. The ratio between the accelerations \ddot{x_a} amd \ddot{x_{in}} is just the inverse of the gear ratio, therefore

\ddot{x_a} = \frac{\ddot{x_{in}}}{\alpha}

so then we get
F_{in} = \frac{I \ddot{x_{in}}}{\alpha^2}

which is the aforementioned gear ratio squared term. And since each state of a cascade elevator is an upduction (gear ratio < 1), that‚Äôs where that formula comes from.
